sen.j: 湯川秀樹（ゆかわひでき、明治40年（1907年）1月23日 - 昭和56年（1981年）9月8日）は、日本の理論物理学者。
sen.e: Hideki YUKAWA (January 23, 1907-September 8, 1981) was a theoretical physical scientist in Japan.
Hideki YUKAWA (January 23, 1907-September 8, 1981) was a theoretical physical scientist in Japan.
Hideki YUKAWA (January 23, 1907-September 8, 1981) was a theoretical physical scientist in Japan.

sen.j: 京都大学・大阪大学名誉教授。
sen.e: He was the professor emeritus of both Kyoto and Osaka University.
He was professor emeritus for both Kyoto and Osaka University.
He was professor emeritus for both Kyoto and Osaka University.

sen.j: 京都市名誉市民。
sen.e: He was also the honored citizen of Kyoto City.
He was also an honored citizen of Kyoto City.
He was also an honored citizen of Kyoto City.

sen.j: 従二位勲一等。
sen.e: He was conferred the Jyunii-Kun Itto (Junior Second Rank, First order of merit).
He was conferred the Jyunii-Kun Itto (Junior Second Rank, First order of merit).
He was conferred the Jyunii-Kun Itto (Junior Second Rank, First order of merit).

sen.j: 博士 (理学)。
sen.e: He took the degree of Doctor of Science.
Doctorate in Science.
Doctorate in Science.

sen.j: 中間子論の提唱などで原子核・素粒子物理学の発展に大きな功績をあげ、1949年、日本人として初めてのノーベル賞を受賞した。
sen.e: Contributing to the development of nuclear and particle physics by advocating the meson theory, he became the first Japanese to win the Nobel Prize in 1949.
Contributed to the development of nuclear and particle physics by advocating the meson theory, he became the first Japanese to win the Nobel Prize in 1949.
Contributed to the development of nuclear and particle physics by advocating the meson theory, he became the first Japanese to win the Nobel Prize in 1949.

sen.j: 1907年、東京市麻布区市兵衛町（現・港区 (東京都)）に地質学者・小川琢治・小雪夫妻の三男として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born to a geological scientist Takuji OGAWA and his wife Koyuki as their third son in Ichibei-cho Town, Azabu-ku Ward, Tokyo City (present Minato-ku Word (Tokyo Prefecture)).
He was born to a geological scientist Takuji OGAWA and his wife Koyuki as their third son in Ichibei-cho Town, Azabu-ku Ward, Tokyo City (present Minato-ku Word (Tokyo Prefecture)).
He was born in 1907 to a geological scientist Takuji OGAWA and his wife Koyuki as their third son in Ichibei-cho Town, Azabu Ward, Tokyo City (present Minato Ward (Tokyo Prefecture)).

sen.j: 1908年、父・琢治の京都帝国大学教授就任に伴い、一家で京都市に移住する。
sen.e: Following his father Takuji's installation as the professor of Kyoto Imperial University (present Kyoto University), his family moved to Kyoto City in 1908.
Following his father Takuji's position as professor of Kyoto Imperial University (present Kyoto University), his family moved to Kyoto City in 1908.
Following his father Takuji's position as professor of Kyoto Imperial University (present Kyoto University), his family moved to Kyoto City in 1908.

sen.j: このため、麻布の家には誕生後1年2ヶ月しか住んでない。
sen.e: Therefore, he lived in the house at Azabu-ku Ward only for fourteen months after his birth.
Therefore, he lived in the house at Azabu-ku Ward for only fourteen months following his birth.
Therefore, he lived in the house at Azabu-ku Ward for only fourteen months following his birth.

sen.j: 1歳から大学までは京都、大学を出て一時大阪や西宮市にいたこともあるが人生の大半は京都で過ごしたことになる。
sen.e: He had lived in Kyoto Prefecture from the age of one until he graduated from university, and had lived in Osaka Prefecture and Nishinomiya City, Hyogo Prefecture for a short period after graduation; he spent the greater part of his life in Kyoto Prefecture.

He lived in Kyoto Prefecture from the age of one until graduating from university, and lived in Osaka Prefecture and Nishinomiya City, Hyogo Prefecture for a short period after graduation; he spent the greater part of his life in Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 湯川は自伝に「私の記憶は京都に移った後から始まる。やはり京都が私の故郷ということになるのかもしれない」と記している。
sen.e: YUKAWA wrote in his autobiography, "The days after we moved to Kyoto can be recollected but those before Kyoto cannot be. Therefore, Kyoto may be called my hometown."
YUKAWA wrote in his autobiography, "The days after we moved to Kyoto can be recollected but those before Kyoto cannot be. Therefore, Kyoto may be called my hometown."
YUKAWA wrote in his autobiography, "The days after we moved to Kyoto can be recollected but those before Kyoto cannot be. Therefore, Kyoto may be called my hometown."

sen.j: 祖父・駒橘は元紀州藩の武士であり、漢学の素養は豊富で、明治以後は洋学を学び晩年までずっとロンドンタイムスを購読し続けた人物であるという。
sen.e: His grandfather Komakitsu OGAWA was originally a samurai (warrior) of the Kishu Domain with a great store of knowledge of Sinology, who studied Western studies after the Meiji period, continuing subscribing to the London Times until his later years.

His grandfather Komakitsu OGAWA was originally a samurai (warrior) of the Kishu Domain with a great store of knowledge of Sinology, who studied Western studies after the Meiji period, and continued to subscribe to to the London Times until his later years.

sen.cmt: to to the London Times → to the London Times

sen.j: 父祖の地が和歌山であるため“和歌山県出身”と紹介されることもある。
sen.e: As his forefathers had lived in Wakayama, he was sometimes introduced as a person came from Wakayama Prefecture.
As his forefathers had lived in Wakayama, he was sometimes introduced as a person who came from Wakayama Prefecture.
As his forefathers had lived in Wakayama, he was sometimes introduced as a person who came from Wakayama Prefecture.

sen.j: 和歌山県出身の実業家松下幸之助の郷里に「松下幸之助君生誕の地」の石碑があり、題字は同郷ということで湯川の筆によって書かれたものである。
sen.e: There is a stone monument showing the birthplace of Konosuke MATSUSHITA, a businessman from Wakayama Prefecture, in MATSUSHITA's hometown, whose title lettering was written by YUKAWA as a person from the same province.

There is a stone monument showcasing the birthplace of Konosuke MATSUSHITA, a businessman from Wakayama Prefecture, in MATSUSHITA's hometown, whose title was written by YUKAWA as a person from the same province.

sen.j: ただし、湯川本人は和歌山で暮らした経験は無い。
sen.e: YUKAWA himself, however, had not lived in Wakayama Prefecture.
YUKAWA himself, however, had not lived in Wakayama Prefecture.
YUKAWA himself, however, had not lived in Wakayama Prefecture.

sen.j: 5、6歳の頃母方の祖父・駒橘より四書の素読を習った。
sen.e: He read aloud the "Shisho (four major Chinese books respected in the Confucianism)" under the tutelage of his maternal grandfather Komakitsu when he was 5 or 6 years old.
He read aloud the "Shisho (four major Chinese books respected in the Confucianism)" under the tutelage of his maternal grandfather Komakitsu when he was 5 or 6 years old.
He read aloud the "Shisho (four major Chinese books respected in the Confucianism)" under the tutelage of his maternal grandfather Komakitsu when he was 5 or 6 years old.

sen.j: 湯川は自伝に｢私はこのころの漢籍の素読を決してむだだったとは思わない。
sen.e: "I have never thought that having read those Chinese classic books in my childhood was useless.
"I have never thought that having read those Chinese classic books in my childhood was useless.
"I have never thought that having read those Chinese classic books in my childhood was useless.

sen.j: …意味もわからずに入っていった漢籍が大きな収穫をもたらしている。
sen.e: Those books have provided me lots of benefits, although I could not construe the Chinese words at first.
Those books provided me with lots of benefits, although I could not construe the Chinese words at first.
Those books provided me with lots of benefits, although I could not construe the Chinese words at first.

sen.j: その後大人の書物をよみ出す時に文字に対する抵抗は全くなかった。
sen.e: I felt no reluctance toward characters when I became old enough to read books written for adults.
I felt no reluctance toward characters when I became old enough to read books written for adults.
I felt no reluctance toward characters when I became old enough to read books written for adults.

sen.j: 漢字に慣れていたからであろう。
sen.e: I had likely gotten used to the Chinese characters.
I had likely gotten used to the Chinese characters.
I had likely gotten used to the Chinese characters.

sen.j: 慣れるということは恐ろしいことだ。
sen.e: Getting used to something produces surprising effect.
Getting used to something produces a surprising effect.
Getting used to something produces a surprising effect.

sen.j: ただ祖父の声につれて復唱するだけで、知らずしらず漢字に親しみその後の読書を容易にしてくれたのは事実である。
sen.e: Merely repeating what my grandfather said undoubtedly facilitated my reading ability by making me familiar with the Chinese characters unconsciously.
Merely repeating what my grandfather said undoubtedly facilitated my reading ability by making me familiar with the Chinese characters unconsciously.
Merely repeating what my grandfather said undoubtedly facilitated my reading ability by making me familiar with the Chinese characters unconsciously.

sen.j: 」と記している。
sen.e: " YUKAWA wrote in his autobiography.

sen.j: 1919年、京都府立洛北中学校・高等学校に入学する。
sen.e: He entered Kyoto First Junior High School (present Kyoto Prefectural Rakuhoku High School) in 1919.
He entered Kyoto First Junior High School (present Kyoto Prefectural Rakuhoku High School) in 1919.

sen.j: 中学時代の湯川はあまり目立たない存在であり、あだ名は｢権兵衛｣だった。
sen.e: He attracted little attention in his junior high school days, who was called "Gonbei".
He attracted little attention in his junior high school days, who was called "Gonbei".

sen.j: 京都一中の同期には学者の子供が多く､後に学者になった者も多かったという。
sen.e: There were a lot of students whose parents were scholars in the same class in Kyoto First Junior High School, therefore many students became scholars later.

sen.j: 同じくノーベル物理学賞を受けた朝永振一郎は一中で一年上、三高・京大では同期だった。
sen.e: Shinichiro TOMONAGA, who also won the Nobel Prize in Physics, was his senior by one year at the junior high school and a classmate in the Third High School under the old system of education (present Kyoto University, general education course) and Kyoto Imperial University.

sen.e: He graduated from the Physics Department, Science Faculty of Kyoto Imperial University in 1929.

sen.j: 同大学玉城嘉十郎研究室の副手となる。

sen.j: 1932年京都帝国大学講師。
sen.e: He became the instructor of Kyoto Imperial University in 1932.

sen.j: 1933年には大阪大学講師を兼担する。
sen.e: He also held the post of the instructor of Osaka Imperial University (present Osaka University).
He also held the post of instructor at Osaka Imperial University (present Osaka University).

sen.j: 教え子の間では、声が小さく講義はかなり難解であったと伝えられている。
sen.e: It is told that his voice was so small that students found difficulty in understanding his lecture.
It is said that his voice was so small that students found it difficult to understand his lectures.

sen.j: この頃、大阪胃腸病院の院長湯川家の婿養子となり、小川姓から湯川姓となる。
sen.e: He was adopted by his wife's family Yukawa, whose family head was the director of Osaka Gastrointestinal Hospital at that time, with changing his family name from Ogawa to Yukawa.

sen.j: 1934年、中間子理論構想を発表、1935年、「素粒子の相互作用について」を発表 中間子の存在を予言する。
sen.e: He put forward the concept of meson theory in 1934 and submitted a thesis "Interaction of the elementary particle" in 1935, predicting the existence of meson.
He put forward the meson theory in 1934 and submitted a thesis "Interaction of the elementary particle" in 1935, predicting the existence of mesons.

sen.j: この研究が評価され、1940年学士院恩賜賞受賞、1943年最年少で文化勲章受章。
sen.e: This research was appreciated, with the result that he was awarded the Gakushi-in Onshi-sho (the Imperial prize of the Imperial Academy (later Japan Academy)) in 1940 and the Order of Culture in 1943, while becoming the youngest winner of the Order of Culture.

This research was appreciated, with the result that he was awarded the Gakushi-in Onshi-sho (the Imperial prize of the Imperial Academy (later Japan Academy)) in 1940 and the Order of Culture in 1943, while becoming the youngest winner of the Order of Culture.

sen.j: さらに1949年、ノーベル物理学賞受賞した。
sen.e: He also won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1949.
He also won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1949.
He also won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1949.

sen.j: これは日本人として初めてのノーベル賞受賞であり、このニュースは敗戦・占領下で自信を失っていた日本国民に大きな力を与えたとされ、フィーバーを巻き起こした。
sen.e: He was the first Japanese to win the Novel Prize, so his feat excited the Japanese nation having lost confidence due to defeat in the Second World War and occupation.
He was the first Japanese to win the Novel Prize, so his feat excited the Japanese nation which had lost its confidence through its defeat in the Second World War and subsequent occupation.
He was the first Japanese to win the Novel Prize, so his feat excited the Japanese nation which had lost its confidence through its defeat in the Second World War and subsequent occupation.

sen.j: その後も非局所場理論・素領域理論といった革新的かつ野心的な理論を提唱しつづけ、最後まで第一線級の物理学者であり続けた。
sen.e: He kept advocating innovative and ambitious theory such as the quantum theory of non-local fields and spectrum theory of elementary particle (素領域理論), and being active at the forefront of the Physics until his last days.
sen.cmt: 素領域理論の訳がわかりません

sen.j: またその一方で、核兵器廃絶を訴える平和運動にも積極的に携わり、ラッセル＝アインシュタイン宣言にマックス・ボルンらと共に共同宣言者として名前を連ねている。
sen.e: He also took part in the peace movement actively for the abolition of nuclear weapons, being among the members including Max Born who jointly published the Russell-Einstein Manifesto.

sen.j: 色紙に何か書いて欲しいと頼まれるとしばしば「知魚楽」と書いた。
sen.e: When he was asked to write something on a shikishi (a square of heavy decorated paper for writing poem, motto and others), he often wrote "知魚楽" in Chinese characters.

sen.j: 『荘子』の「秋水」の最後の一句である。
sen.e: This is the last phrase in a book written by Zhuang-zi, an ancient Chinese philosopher.
sen.cmt: 秋水の中国語読みがわかりません。秋水は本の固有題名なので正しい読みが必要と考え，一冊の本という訳にしました。

sen.cmt: 秋水の訳、および『荘子』の補足説明。

sen.j: 1981年、肺炎に心不全を併発し京都市左京区の自宅で死去する。

sen.j: 広島平和公園にある若葉の像の台座に、湯川による短歌の銘文「まがつびよ ふたたびここに くるなかれ 平和をいのる 人のみぞここは」が刻まれている。
sen.e: "Malicious god, leave and never return to our society! Our society welcomes only people praying for peace." is the tanka (thirty-one syllables' poem)-styled epitaph, which is inscribed on the pedestal of the statue of "Wakaba (young leaves)" in the Hiroshima Heiwa-koen Park.

sen.j: - 京都大学退官、京都大学名誉教授

sen.j: - 死去
sen.e: He died.

sen.e: He had two elder brothers; Yoshiki OGAWA (a metallurgist and the professor of the University of Tokyo) and Shigeki KAIZUKA (a scholar of Oriental history, the professor emeritus of Kyoto University, and a winner of the Order of Culture).
